studyName: Ras Umm Sidd 245 Year Coral d18O, Sr/Ca, SST and d18Osw Data

investigators: Felis, T.; Ionita, M.; Rimbu, N.; Lohmann, G.; Kölling, M.
studyNotes: Coral oxygen isotope (d18O) and strontium/calcium data and reconstructed sea surface temperature and d18Oseawater from northern Red Sea coral RUS-95 collected off Ras Umm Sidd, Egypt, for the past 245 years.  Data are presented at both annual and bimonthly resolution.

author.name: Thomas Felis, Jürgen Pätzold, Yossi Loya, Maoz Fine, Ahmed H. Nawar, Gerold Wefer

publication.title: A coral oxygen isotope record from the northern Red Sea documenting NAO, ENSO, and North Pacific teleconnections on Middle East climate variability since the year 1750
publication.citation: Thomas Felis, Jürgen Pätzold, Yossi Loya, Maoz Fine, Ahmed H. Nawar, Gerold Wefer. 2000. A coral oxygen isotope record from the northern Red Sea documenting NAO, ENSO, and North Pacific teleconnections on Middle East climate variability since the year 1750. Paleoceanography, 15(6), 679-694. doi: 10.1029/1999PA000477

author.name: Thomas Felis, Monica Ionita, Norel Rimbu, Gerrit Lohmann, Martin Kölling

publication.title: Mild and Arid Climate in the Eastern Sahara-Arabian Desert During the Late Little Ice Age
publication.citation: Thomas Felis, Monica Ionita, Norel Rimbu, Gerrit Lohmann, Martin Kölling. 2018. Mild and Arid Climate in the Eastern Sahara-Arabian Desert During the Late Little Ice Age. Geophysical Research Letters, 45. doi: 10.1029/2018GL078617
publication.abstract: The climate of the Sahara and Arabian Deserts during the Little Ice Age is not well known, due to a lack of annually resolved natural and documentary archives. We present an annual reconstruction of temperature and aridity derived from Sr/Ca and oxygen isotopes in a coral of the desert-surrounded northern Red Sea. Our data indicate that the eastern Sahara and Arabian Deserts did not experience pronounced cooling during the late Little Ice Age (~1750-1850) but suggest an even more arid mean climate than in the following ~150 years. The mild temperatures are broadly in line with predominantly negative phases of the North Atlantic Oscillation during the Little Ice Age. The more arid climate is best explained by meridional advection of dry continental air from Eurasia. We find evidence for an abrupt termination of the more arid climate after 1850, coincident with a reorganization of the atmospheric circulation over Europe.
